At that time, the Bodhisattva, abiding in the power of loving-kindness and patience, endured all of it without any anger or resentment.

We will sever their life-force for you!
At that time, the Bodhisattva said to those people:
Good men, do not speak like this.
If one kills, one will accomplish evil karma.
Even if someone were to cut up my body into pieces like jujube leaves, I would never give rise to a thought of killing.
Why is this?
Those who kill will fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, and animal realms. Even if they attain a human body, their parents will still not love them and they will always be hated by the masses.
Good man!
All dharmas are generally of two kinds:
First, wholesome dharmas, second, unwholesome dharmas.
Due to unwholesome dharmas, one falls into evil destinies. If one relies on wholesome dharmas, one will obtain blessings and benefits.
At that time, Bodhisattva Good and Obedient, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Wholesome and unwholesome are like planting, all following karma's birth.
How could there be bitter seeds as a cause, yet a sweet fruit ripening?
The present Dharma is seen like this, the wise should contemplate.
Suffering repays evil conditions, being wholesome is always blissful.

At that time, the person transformed by the Heavenly Emperor, having heard these words, thought to himself that he could not make that Bodhisattva commit the karma of killing, and suddenly disappeared.
At that time, the Heavenly Emperor again transformed into a heap of gold and silver treasures, and had the men go to the Bodhisattva's place and say these words:
You can take these precious treasures and use them as you wish.
At that time, the Bodhisattva said to those people:
Good men, do not say such things.
Why is it so?
Stealing can cause sentient beings to become poor, lowly, without support or refuge.
Even if I am poor and my life is in danger, I will never engage in taking what is not given.
You should know that ordinary foolish people are greedy, covetous, and obscured. How could a wise person engage in taking what is not given?

Although they may have nothing at all, if they abide in a mind of renunciation,
The wise say that such a person is the most wealthy and noble in the world.
The wise one is free from all evil and is upright in everything,
Fools, due to committing offenses, become ugly all over.ğŸ”½The wise encourage the cultivation of goodness, while fools always do evil.
It is better to endure the scolding of the wise than to accept the praise of fools.
Then the person transformed by Indra, having heard these words, left in disappointment.

At that time, the Bodhisattva spoke a verse again, saying:
The person who lies always has a foul mouth, and enters the evil paths of suffering,

As for the person who lies, they deceive themselves, and also deceive devas, nÄgas, and mahoragas.

Having thought like this, he went before the Bodhisattva, abandoned his arrogance, bowed his head to the Bodhisattva's feet, and asked in verse:

At that time, after the Bodhisattva said this, he again spoke a verse, saying:
If a person is greedy and seeks much, accumulating wealth without being content,

In body, life, and wealth, always thinking of their impermanence.

Water is not satiated by clouds, the ocean is not satiated by water,
The king is now also like this, how can there be a time of satiation?

The king is now also like this, until the end of life there is no rest.

The wise are also like this, never failing to practice goodness.

All are impure, the wise should abandon them.
At that time, King Prasenajit, having heard these words, inwardly felt ashamed and said to the Bodhisattva:

'King Prasenajit is the poorest in this city.

Relying on his royal status, he has never had compassion for sentient beings, oppressing and deceiving them, wantonly causing harm, greedy and covetous, covered by desire, not knowing contentment.'

'The World-Honored One, the Great Teacher, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, who has abandoned afflictions and the impurities of anger without remainder, who is impartial towards all sentient beings, shall bear witness.'

At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to subdue King Prasenajit, said to him:

At that time, after King Prasenajit spoke this verse, he addressed the Buddha, saying:

I now give rise to the unsurpassed great mind of enlightenment, wishing to bring peace and liberation to sentient beings from the bonds of birth and death.

All the gardens, ponds, flowers, and fruits that I possess, I wish to offer to the supreme Tathagata and the assembly of monks.

At that time, the five hundred elders of the state of Kosala, having witnessed this, all gave rise to the supreme great bodhi mind.
